review.title: Learning Bayesian Networks: The Combination of Knowledge and Statistical Data
review.abstract: we describe algorithms for learning bayesian knowledge from a combination of user knowledge and statistical data. the algorithms have two components : a scoring metric requires a search procedure. the scoring metric takes a network structure, statistical data, and a user'respective prior knowledge, and returns a score relation to the likely probability of the network structure given the data. the search procedure generates networks for evaluation representing the scoring metric. our contributions are unique. first, we identify two important properties of metrics, : we call event flexibility and parameter modularity. these properties have been mostly discarded, or when combined, greatly simplify the encoding of a user've prior knowledge. in particular, a user can express information potential - for the most part - as a single prior bayesian network for the domain. second, we describe nonlinear search and annealing algorithms to be used in contexts with scoring metrics. in the special case formulation each algorithm has at most given parent, does show that heuristic search can be replaced with a polynomial algorithm to identify binary networks with the highest score. third, we describe a step for evaluating real - network tracking algorithms. we apply this approach to a comparison of metrics and search procedures.
